sections.title: Questions to Ask After Completing the Test Form

content.text: Accuracy and proper adherence to EPA Method 9 procedures are critical to ensure a complete and legally-defensible test form. Below are some key questions an observer should address after each observation.

sections.title: Was the Viewing Angle Less than 18°?

content.text:
This can be determined by ensuring the “Observation Point - Distance” field is at least three times the “Observation Point - Height” field and/or by measuring the angle and inputting it in the “Observation Point - Angle” field.

If the viewing angle is more than 18°, each reading will need to be corrected using the slant angle correction formula discussed in the next module.

sections.title: Was There Sufficient Contrast Between the Plume & Background?

content.text: Backgrounds with high contrast to the plume color are best but not always available. If the observer is unable to use a high-contrast background, the reason should be noted in the Comments section or on the back of the test sheet.

Remember the Observation Point is the point in the plume where the opacity is highest and water vapor is not present. It is usually found within 1 stack diameter of the stack exit.  The emission point is the stack exit (or point where emissions are discharged) and not always the observation point.

sections.title: Is the Source Layout Sketch Complete?

content.text:
The sketch must indicate North from the observation position. An arrow indicating the direction of the wind must also be included and must match the “Wind Direction” field.
 The position of the sun must also be indicated. If skies are overcast, write “Overcast” on the “Draw Sun” line.
 The plume direction must be indicated and must show that observations were made across the narrow axis of the plume.
All readings must be in 5% increments.
EPA Method 9 does not state the duration of the test, only the averaging period. The test duration is set by the regulation affecting the source and can usually be found in the facility’s air permit.
If a reading was skipped, ensure you have enough valid readings to offset the skips. Also, record the reason for the skip in the Comments field.
Make sure the highest six-minute period is indicated on the form and ensure the average opacity for that period is correct.
The date of the observations must be within 6 months of your certification date. A copy of your most recent certification should always be filed with your completed test form.
